tossups.question: Gilbert’s [jheel-BEAR’s] syndrome causes this organ to have difficulty processing a compound produced from the breakdown of hemoglobin. The Ito [EE-toe] cells in this organ store vitamin A in a region between the sinusoids and hepatocytes known as the space of Disse. Though not the brain, (*) Wilson’s disease causes a buildup of copper in this organ, and star-shaped cells in this organ are responsible for removing particulate contaminants from the blood and are known as Kupffer cells. For 10 points, identify this organ which is responsible for the synthesis of cholesterol and the secretion of bile and which can be harmed by jaundice or cirrhosis.

This author wrote multiple novels on themes from his country’s history. One, “On the Field of Glory,” is about the greatest king of this author’s country at the Battle of Vienna. In another, this author discusses the title knights who are defeated by an alliance of this author’s country with Lithuania; that work about the (*) Battle of Grunwald [GROON-vahld] is “The Teutonic Knights.” “The Trilogy” is a trio of novels by this author about conflicts between his home country with Ukraine, Sweden, and the Ottoman Empire, respectively. Those works and others led to this author being awarded the 1905 Nobel Prize in Literature. For 10 points, name the Polish author of “Quo Vadis,” a novel not about Poland but about ancient Rome.

136 bars of this chord appears for four minutes straight in one prelude depicting the motion of the river Rhine, and Robert Schumann’s visit to the Rhineland inspired his third symphony, which is also in this key. A nocturne by Chopin in this key begins with the right hand playing a major sixth up to the third of this key, followed by scale degrees 2-3-2... 1. In addition to that (*) Opus 9 Number 2 work, other pieces in this key include Haydn’s Joke Quartet, an Octet by Mendelssohn, and Beethoven’s Emperor Concerto. Beethoven viewed this key as majestic and heroic, which refers back to the nickname given to his Symphony Number 3 in this key, “Eroica.” For 10 points, name this key with three flats, which is the relative major of C minor.

This play contains a parabasis [puh-RAB-uh-sis] that addresses the audience as “enfeebled and powerless creatures of earth.” Famous real-life figures make appearances in this play, including the geometer Meton, who gives a set of town-plans to the protagonist, and the much-ridiculed poet Cinesias. At the end of this play, the protagonist is ultimately able to negotiate with the barbaric (*) Triballus and marries Zeus’s daughter Sovereignty. The major plot point in this play concerns a blockade that prevents humans’ offerings from reaching Mount Olympus, a plan that is formulated with the help of the Hoopoe Epops and Euelpides [you-ELL-pi-deez]. For 10 points, name this Greek comedy in which Pisthetaerus [piz-thuh-TEAR-uss] leads in the construction of Cloud-cuckoo-land, written by Aristophanes.

The first full transcript of this speech was published in The Washington Post in 1983, fifteen years after its speaker had died. Rabbi Joachim Prinz spoke prior to the oration of this speech, of which one section was improvised by request of the singer Mahalia Jackson. The beginning of this speech states that “Five score years ago, a great American, in whose symbolic shadow we stand, signed the (*) Emancipation Proclamation.” Delivered on the steps of the Lincoln Memorial, this speech, the defining moment of the March on Washington for Jobs and Freedom, ended by saying, “free at last, Great God a-mighty, we are free at last.” For 10 points, name this famous Martin Luther King, Jr. speech.

Joan Miró’s painting The Tilled Field shows a background sky of this color. Salvador Dalí’s painting The Great Masturbator features a giant distorted face of this color in the shape of a rock formation, and in Marc Chagall’s I and the Village, the (*) chapel and rightmost house are this color. A 1925 Kandinsky painting is titled after this color with red and blue, and JMW Turner experimented with the Indian pigment of this color derived from the urine of mango-fed cows. Though not green, this is the color of the titular figure hanging on a cross in a painting by Paul Gauguin. For 10 points, give this color that covers most of van Gogh’s Sunflower.

One of these stories tells of Romos, a son of Odysseus and Circe who leaves home by ship. The two most well known of these stories famously differ in that the first is based on fratricide, rape, and sheltering of criminals, where the second is based on the noble travels of a (*) Trojan War survivor. To resolve the problem of a nearly 700 year gap between those two well-known stories about this, ancient authors compiled a list of Alban kings who supposedly ruled in that gap. In one of these stories, the king offers shelter to criminals and vagrants to build a population of men, and abducts the Sabine Women as their brides. For 10 points, name these stories, which include stories of Romulus killing his brother Remus, and Aeneas ruling the city of Alba Longa.
tossups.answer: foundation myths of Rome [accept clear equivalents] <Yoshida>

tossups.question: This man first put down a coup d’etat by Lao Ai, who had a longtime secret correspondence with this man’s mother, Lady Zhao. Following this man’s death, two carriages carrying rotten fish were drawn behind this man’s wagon in order to hide the smell of this man’s decaying body. The conquests of this man’s kingdom ultimately brought about the end of the (*) Warring States. This man, aside from constructing the precursor of the Great Wall of China, also consumed a deadly quantity of mercury, having believed that he would achieve immortality. For 10 points, name this first emperor of China, the mastermind of the Terracotta Army.
tossups.answer: Shi Huangdi [or Qin Shi Huang or Ying Zheng or Zhao Zheng] <Halza>
tossups.answer_formatted: Shi Huangdi [or Qin Shi Huang or Ying Zheng or Zhao Zheng]

tossups.question: The Danakil Depression, in this country’s Afar Regional State, is home to the world’s hottest town of Dallol. This country maintains control of the Ogaden region, which was the object of a war with its eastern neighbor in the late 1970s. This country’s Omo River flows in the southern region of this nation. The largest lake in this nation, (*) Lake Tana, sources the Blue Nile prior to flowing into this nation’s western neighbor. The nation of Eritrea achieved independence from this nation in 1993. For 10 points, name this mountainous nation located in the Horn of Africa, with capital at Addis Ababa.

One work titled for the “Blues” of this place chronicles the positive and negative experiences of Native American children. In a work partially set in this location, James Castle commits suicide by jumping out of a window. In another work set in this type of place, Pudge is guided through his own (*) “labyrinth of suffering” and the title character dies while driving drunk to her mother’s grave; that work is set in a location of this type called Culver Creek. In another novel set in this type of institution, the protagonist feels uncomfortable when Mr. Antolini strokes his head, which occurs after the protagonist was expelled from a place of this type called Pencey Prep. For 10 points, name this institution attended by protagonists of Looking for Alaska and Catcher in the Rye.

A coordinate specification named for this scientist has the origin centered on a fluid parcel as it moves through space and time. This man was the first to write the variational form of an equation he often co-names describing the fundamental classical laws of motion known as D'Alembert's principle. A set of (*) points named for this scientist expand on the three discovered by Euler and give special solutions to the three-body problem. This scientist also reformulated classical mechanics using his namesake multipliers. For 10 points, identify this Italian-French scientist who names a quantity given by the kinetic energy minus the potential energy as well as the points L1 through L5.

One member of this profession searches for his lost cat and is aided by his assistant Louise Munroe; that man is Jackson Brodie and was included in a novel series by Kate Atkinson. Another member of this profession is called the greatest one of this profession of all time and sends Miss Carnaby two hundred pounds prior to the conclusion of her dog-kidnapping campaign in (*) The Nemean Lion. Yet another member of this profession appears to know nothing of “literature, philosophy and politics,” according to his assistant. That member of this profession faked his own death at Reichenbach Falls and was enamored by Irene Adler in “A Scandal in Bohemia.” For 10 points, identify this profession of Agatha Christie’s Hercule Poirot and Arthur Conan Doyle’s Sherlock Holmes.

This man and Malcolm III Canmore signed the Treaty of Abernethy to end a war this man initiated. This man also established a feudal system with the Oath of Salisbury, and received the blessing of Pope Alexander II before starting a violent campaign. Edwin and Morcar started a rebellion against this man, who responded with a campaign called the (*) Harrying of the North. This man’s half-brother Odo helped suppress the Revolt of the Earls under this man’s rule and commissioned a famous depiction of him. This man endeavored to calculate the estimated total value of all land in his country, leading him to commission the Domesday Book. For 10 points, name this Norman leader who invaded England and emerged victorious at the Battle of Hastings.
tossups.answer: William the Conqueror [or William I of England, William II of Normandy, or William the Bastard] <Jin>
tossups.answer_formatted: William the Conqueror [or William I of England, William II of Normandy, or William the Bastard]
acceptable: William I of England, William II of Normandy,

tossups.question: The first industrial process to produce the pure form of this element involved leaching salt from a reaction held at a thousand degrees Celsius; that process has the reactants sodium and a compound of this element bound to four chlorine atoms and is known as the Hunter process. A dioxide of this element used as a (*) white pigment is known as rutile, and that dioxide is treated with chlorine gas and reduced by liquid magnesium in the most widely-used process to commercially produce this element, the Kroll process. For 10 points, name this paramagnetic metal known for its lightweight alloys, which follows scandium on the periodic table and has atomic number 22 and symbol Ti.

This work of art was stored alongside the Venus de Milo in the Château de Valençay during World War II. The base of this sculpture contains the word “Rhodios” and was most likely erected by Antigonus II Gonata to commemorate the Battle of Cos in 255 BC. This sculpture’s subject is represented likely standing at the (*) prow of a ship as evidenced by her clothing, which appears to be billowing in the wind. This sculpture was discovered by Charles Champoiseau in 1863 on an Aegean island, and currently resides without arms or a head at the Daru Staircase in the Louvre. For 10 points, identify this Hellenistic sculpture depicting the Greek goddess of victory.
tossups.answer: Winged Victory of Samothrace [or Nike of Samothrace] <Jin>

tossups.question: In one story, this deity splits into three parts and becomes known as Tripathaga. This deities’ death is often seen as one of the signs of the end of the Kali Yuga. When this deity destroyed the fields of Jahnu, he consumed her, and only after begging from the other gods was she released. The souls of the (*) six thousand sons of Sagara were cleansed by this deity, though she tried to destroy the entire world first. Bhagiratha prayed that Shiva would stop this deity from doing so, and Shiva trapped her in his hair, and redirected her anger, resulting in the common image of Shiva with flowing hair. For 10 points, name this deity, the personification of a vast purifying river in Hindu Religion.

During the Lepers’ Plot of 1321, King Philip V [“the fifth”] ordered about five thousand lepers who had been accused of poisoning wells to be killed in this way. Jacques de Molay and William Tyndale died in this manner, and Charles the Bad died through these means after his physician wrapped him from (*) neck to toe in linen cloth soaked with brandy. Only six deaths were recorded in an event of this type that began at the bakery of Thomas Farriner on Pudding Lane; that event caused the destruction of a large portion of houses and churches in London in 1666. For 10 points, identify this means of death which Diocletian used to kills Christians and destroy their scriptures, and which Nero was purported to have ignored by playing the fiddle.
tossups.answer: fire [or being burned at the stake or combustion or flames] <McMaken>
tossups.answer_formatted: fire [or being burned at the stake or combustion or flames]

tossups.question: This concept traces its roots to the writings of 14th-century philosopher Ibn Khaldun. Empirical studies have found that the optimal point on this concept occurs at a 70% tax rate while other studies claim the optimal point on this thing is at 32%. This concept was popularized after it was (*) drawn on a napkin during a meeting in 1974 by its namesake author. This concept was rooted in the supply-side school of economics and was used to justify the Kemp-Roth Tax Cut of 1981 and Reaganomics. For 10 points, name this economic concept that illustrates the relationship between tax rates and government revenue.

One observer of this event tweeted, “Immigrants they get the job done” with regards to a participant in this event, even though the participant was born in America. A participant in this event, Bruno Massot, received citizenship in his naturalized country only three months prior to this event. The “Garlic Girls” from the home nation of this event produced an unprecedented run in their respective (*) sport, before conceding to Sweden prior to the tenth end. Red-uniformed cheerleading squads led choreographed chants at multiple venues at this event. U.S. Vice President Mike Pence and North Korean figure Kim Yo-jong sat next to each other at the Opening Ceremony of, for 10 points, what February 2018 international sporting event.
tossups.answer: XXIII [“twenty-third”] Olympic Winter Games [accept 2018 Winter Olympics or PyeongChang 2018 prior to “2018”] <Halza, Leberer>

tossups.question: In the unit circle, the chord of an angle can be found by multiplying this constant by the sine of half of that angle. The Euler characteristic of the connected sum of two surfaces can be found by subtracting this constant from the sum of the Euler characteristics of each surface, since the connected sum removes this number of faces. For any polyhedron, this number is equal to the number of (*) vertices minus edges plus faces. This sixth decimal digit of pi is also the ones digit of the constant which is the base of the natural logarithm, Euler’s number “e.” For 10 points, name this smallest number of points in Euclidean space needed to determine a line, which is also the smallest prime number.

In this myth system, one god crushes a jellyfish for failing to bring a monkey’s liver back to him. A goddess in the myth system eats the food of the underworld, and becomes hideous. That goddess declared that she would kill a thousand people a day, and her husband retorted that he would bring back 1500. That goddess from this system had died giving birth to the (*) fire god. In this myth system, the moon god killed the food goddess when she threw up her meal, and the storm god killed an eight-headed, eight-tailed dragon by getting all of the heads drunk and then cutting the beast to pieces. For 10 points, name this myth system, where the sun goddess hid in a cave when her brother Susano’o threw a flayed pony into her chamber.

bonuses.leadin: One character in this work states that “everybody's youth is a dream, a form of chemical madness” while discussing childhood with his friend’s sister. For 10 points each:
answers: “The Diamond as Big as the Ritz”
parts: Name this novella in which John T. Unger goes to the middle of nowhere in Montana to visit his classmate, whose father owns the title object.
“The Diamond as Big as the Ritz” was included in the collection Tales of the Jazz Age, written by this Lost Generation American author.

Fitzgerald wrote this essay, the first in a group of three that were published in Esquire magazine in 1936. It starts with the pessimistic quote, “Of course all life is a process of breaking down,” reflecting the author’s mental state at the time.
answers_formatted: “The Diamond as Big as the Ritz”
acceptable: “The Diamond as Big as the Ritz”

bonuses.leadin: In giraffes, this structure can run up to fifteen feet long, from the top of its neck to its front toe. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these cytoplasmic protrusions from the cell body of a neuron, which transmit electrical signals received by dendrites.
A giant axon a millimeter thick in the longfin inshore species of this animal was famously studied by Hodgkin and Huxley. That axon in this creature controls its water jet propulsion system.
The longest axons in the human body are those of this nerve, which runs from the base of the spinal cord through the buttock to the big toe.

bonuses.leadin: According to preterists, this event occurred in 70 C.E. with the sacking of Jerusalem. For 10 points each:
answers: the Second Coming of Jesus [or the Second Advent; prompt on the day of the Lord]
parts: Name this event described by the Greek word parousia, in which the Messiah returns “like a thief in the night.”

Dispensationalists believe that after the rapture and a period of tribulation, Jesus will reign on Earth for this many years before the final judgment and the establishment of the New Heaven and Earth.

The length of the tribulation is usually interpreted to be seven years by the “Seventy Weeks Prophecy” in this book of the Bible, in which Gabriel speaks to the title prophet while in exile in Babylon.
answers_formatted: the Second Coming of Jesus [or the Second Advent; prompt on the day of the Lord]

bonuses.leadin: In this work, Plato points towards the sky as Aristotle motions his hand downwards. For 10 points each:
answers: The School of Athens [or Scuola di Atene]
parts: Name this fresco from the Italian Renaissance that depicts various philosophers.
The School of Athens is the masterpiece of this Renaissance artist who also created Transfiguration and Saint George and the Dragon.
In the center foreground of The School of Athens, Heraclitus in a purple cloak is depicted in the guise of this other Renaissance painter and architect as he writes at a desk.

bonuses.leadin: The history of the United States has been occasionally marked by incursions of the freedom of speech. For 10 points each,
parts: This lawsuit, brought to the Supreme Court in 1984, held that the burning of the American flag was a protected form of speech.
This bill, passed by a Federalist-dominated Congress under John Adams, sought to forbid “false, scandalous, or malicious writing.”

In one of the earliest cases addressing freedom of speech, this German-American printer was accused of libel in 1733 after criticizing colonial governor William Cosby in his newspaper, The New York Weekly Journal.

bonuses.leadin: Characters within this group of novels include Al-Sayyid Ahmad and Kamal Abd al-Jawad, who may have been based on the author himself. For 10 points each:
answers: The Day the Leader was Killed <Jin>
parts: Name this group of novels that follow the three generations of the Abd al-Jawad family, with book titles named after real-life streets in the author’s hometown.
This Egyptian author wrote the Cairo Trilogy as well as the novel Children of Gebelawi, a novel that resulted in him getting stabbed in the neck by Muslim extremists 35 years after its publication.
Mahfouz wrote about the assassination of President Anwar Sadat in this aptly-titled novel, which is told from the point of view of the Muhtashimi family.
acceptable: The Day the Leader was Killed <Jin>

bonuses.leadin: Militaries have crossed the English Channel for millennia, either in pursuit or as the pursued. For 10 points each:
parts: This man’s forces were responsible for the first foreign invasion of England in 55 BC. That invasion by this man was justified on the grounds that enemies opposing his conquest of Gaul in 58 BC had retreated across the English Channel.

The Battle of Quiberon Bay in this war stymied France’s plans to invade England by crossing the English Channel through a devastation of French naval forces. During this war, William Pitt the Elder acted as Great Britain’s war minister.

During World War II, a mass exodus of over 300,000 British troops was executed from the French port of Dunkirk during this operation. Over 800 ships, many of which were civilian owned, executed this operation.

bonuses.leadin: See how well you know your vitamins, for 10 points each:
parts: Ascorbic acid is the name usually given for the vitamin known by this letter. This vitamin is found in citrus fruits and can help prevent scurvy.
Deficiency of this vitamin can cause a medical condition in which the eye fails to produce tears. It is found in fish, dairy products, and meat, and has the chemical name retinol.
Vitamin B9 has this chemical name. This vitamin can help prevent anemia, and it is found in many leafy vegetables, leading to its Latin root, the word for “leaf.”

bonuses.leadin: This character has dreams of his impending death, and a wife of his recommends that he take laxatives. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this often adapted character who closed his eyes and sang to prove his worth, and was abducted by a fox. He is the protagonist of The Nun’s Priest’s Tale.
Along with The Nun’s Priest’s Tale, Chaucer included this story in The Canterbury Tales. This tale tells of Palamon and Arcite [AR-see-tay], who fight for Emily’s love.
John Fletcher and William Shakespeare wrote this adaptation of the Knight’s Tale. In it, Palamon and Arcite fought for Creon, until Theseus defeated and imprisoned them.

bonuses.leadin: Answer some questions about the language of the Pirahã [pee-duh-HA] people in the Amazon, for 10 points each:
parts: Study of the language of the Pirahãs has caused many to reevaluate the Universal Grammar proposed by this MIT linguist, since it does not contain numbers, past or future tenses, recursion, or other supposedly ubiquitous concepts included in this man’s work Syntactic Structures.

The Pirahã language is believed to have either ten or eleven of these fundamental units of sound that do not convey meaning by themselves. Those consist of three vowels and either seven or eight consonants.

In transcribing the Pirahã language, an “x” is used to denote this phoneme that is produced by abruptly obstructing airflow through the entrance of the vocal folds. In English, this phoneme occurs in the interjection “uh-oh” and can be used in place of a “t” in the words “cat” and “button.”

bonuses.leadin: In ray diagrams, these things are represented by two intersecting curved lines. For 10 points each:
parts: Name these objects, the concave types of which bulge inward and cause light to diverge.
All rays of light entering a lens parallel to the optic axis will exit the lens in a line intersecting this point.

This type of lens has its surface broken up by narrow, stepped rings that save space and mass to produce shorter focal lengths and larger apertures. It is often used in lighthouses, and its namesake French physicist coined the term linear polarization.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following questions to display your knowledge of vexillology, for 10 points each:
parts: This country’s flag is the only one in the world that is not a quadrilateral. It has a blue border and a crimson background in the shape of two stacked pennons.
From 1977 to 2011, this country’s flag consisted solely of the color green. This country’s current flag has red, black, and green horizontal stripes with a white star and crescent in the center.

In addition to Guatemala, this country’s flag is the only other one in the world to feature a firearm. It has a horizontal tricolor of green, black, and yellow with a red triangle on the left housing an AK-47.

bonuses.leadin: The Pope who lends his name to this musical style was said to have received it from a dove representing the Holy Spirit. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Western musical tradition that gained prominence in the ninth and tenth centuries and that consists of monophonic, unaccompanied singing of the Roman Rite.

Each work of Gregorian chant can be classified by this pitch organization scheme that includes eight categories based on the pitches used, the final, and the reciting tone. They can be either authentic or plagal and include the Hypomixolydian and the Phrygian.
This term refers to the refrain of a Psalm alternated with its verses. The style of chant named for this term consists of two choirs singing in alternation.

bonuses.leadin: This poet wrote about “masks and bergamasques,” whose music “makes the birds in the trees dream / And sob with ecstasy.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this French poet who wrote the poetry collection Saturnine Poems. He was a lover of another French poet, Arthur Rimbaud.

This Verlaine poem was included in Saturnine Poems and was used to send messages during World War II. Specifically, its first line, “wound my heart with a monotonous languor,” was used to signal that Operation Overlord would start in 48 hours.

The third section of T. S. Eliot’s “The Waste Land” contains the line “Et, ô ces voix d'enfants chantant dans la coupole!” [“et, oh say vwah den-fahn shan-tahn dahns la coo-pole”], which is taken from the last line of this Verlaine poem about the titular knight.

bonuses.leadin: Some popular performers of this style include Charlie Christian and Sonny Rollins. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this jazz style characterized by complex chord progressions and a really fast tempo, exemplified by Dizzy Gillespie’s “Shaw 'Nuff.”
This leading musician of the bebop era played alto saxophone on “Shaw ‘Nuff.” He is also known for his pieces “Crazeology,” “Ko-Ko,” and “Ornithology.”

The chord structure of “Crazeology” consists of the namesake “changes” based on this song by George Gershwin. It consists of a thirty-two bar A-B-B-A form with the chords I, vi, ii, V [“one, six, two, five”] followed by a circle of fourths.

bonuses.leadin: The platform Moral Machine was created by MIT Media Lab to help autonomous vehicles with this scenario. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this thought experiment in which you have to decide whom to kill by a switchtrack for the namesake runaway vehicle.

If you have the choice to switch a track for a runaway trolley heading towards a group of five murderers so that it instead kills one innocent bystander, proponents of this ethical theory like Henry Sidgwick would say that it is obligatory to switch the track regardless of innocence, because five is greater than one.

The choice to push a fat man into the track to stop the trolley and save five lives at the expense of one explores this principle, which states that you may take action which has bad side effects, but deliberately intending harm is wrong even if for good causes.

bonuses.leadin: Izanagi needed to cleanse himself when he returned from the underworld, and doing so produced some interesting results. For 10 points each:
answers: Tsukuyomi-no-Mikoto [do not accept or prompt on Tsuki]
parts: When Izanagi washed his face, Susano’o was born from his nose, Amaterasu from his left eye, and this moon god was born from his right eye.
The three deities also had an influence on the three imperial regalia of Japan, which consist of The Grass Cutting Sword, the Eight-Sided Mirror, and one of these objects.
Another Japanese deity with jewels was the god Ryujin. In Japanese mythology, Ryujin famously used his jewels to do this action.

bonuses.leadin: This theory was first proposed by Abraham Ortelius in 1596, and has been supplanted with the discovery of mechanisms such as sea-floor spreading and mantle convection. For 10 points each:
answers: theory of continental drift [do not accept or prompt on plate tectonics because Wegener was only involved in the theory of continental drift]
parts: Name this geologic theory formulated by Alfred Wegener that states the Earth’s crust is composed of plates that move relative to each other over time.
These zones occur as a result of tensional tectonic forces, creating grabens and half-grabens as well as forming new crustal material.
This large region in East Africa runs almost four thousand miles and is an aulacogen, a rift zone formed when one plate in a triple junction is overtaken by the other two plates.
answers_formatted: theory of continental drift [do not accept or prompt on "plate tectonics because Wegener was only involved in the theory of continental drift"]
rejectable: plate tectonics because Wegener was only involved in the theory of continental drift

bonuses.leadin: The exiled leaders of this short-lived European state were captured in the Sigmaringen enclave in April 1945. For 10 points each:
answers: Henri Philippe Benoni Omer Joseph Pétain [or Marshal Pétain]
parts: Name this Nazi German puppet state in southern France, named for the small spa town that acted as its capital.

This man was Vichy France’s head of state for the five years of its existence. Known to some as the Lion of Verdun, this man was hailed as a national hero despite being sentenced to life imprisonment for treason.

French North Africa, a possession of Vichy France, was invaded in 1942 by a combined British and American force in this operation. This operation was the second advance into Axis-occupied North Africa following the defeat at the Battle of El Alamein.
answers_formatted: Henri Philippe Benoni Omer Joseph Pétain [or Marshal Pétain]
acceptable: Henri Philippe Benoni Omer Joseph Pétain

bonuses.leadin: Famed explorer and circumnavigator Ferdinand Magellan was killed in 1521 at the Battle of Mactan in this country. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this country, which was colonized by Spain from 1565-1898 out of the city of Manila.

During World War II, tens of thousands of Filipino and American P.O.W.s were sent on a death march named for this Philippine peninsula. Over ten thousand Filipino P.O.W.s were killed on this death march.
Following twenty years of rule by Ferdinand Marcos, this woman became the first female president of the Philippines in 1986. She is best known for reinstating a bicameral congress in the Philippines.

bonuses.leadin: Each country has its own classic Christmas cuisine. For 10 points each:
answers: pierogies [do not accept or prompt on dumpling]
KFC [accept Kentucky Fried Chicken, but if they mess up don’t take it] <Yoshida>
parts: In Poland, this type of dumpling is a Christmas staple. Krakow has a yearly festival celebrating this food item.
Smalahove is a Western Norwegian dish eaten before Christmas. It is a dish made from the head of one of these animals.
In Japan, rather than cooking at home, many families get food from this restaurant to celebrate.
answers_formatted: KFC [accept Kentucky Fried Chicken, but if they mess up don’t take it]
acceptable: Kentucky Fried Chicken, but if they mess up don’t take it
